title: Edgar Rodriguez-Huerta
text:
Biography
Edgar Rodríguez-Huerta works as part of the Measurement and Geographies Programme to research the interactions among socio-ecological systems, climate change and modern slavery. He conducts quantitative research through multiple systemic-thinking approaches such as Social Life Cycle Assessment and secondary data analysis, climate modelling, societal metabolism, and complex networks to explore the human dimensions of different supply chains (i.e. food supply, solar panels and brick kilns). He completed a PhD in Sustainability Science and with his background in data science and Business Intelligence, he is an enthusiast in data visualization to communicate and publish the technical results among stakeholders and facilitate decision making

title: Luís Henrique da Costa Leão
text:
Biography
Doctor in Sciences in the area of Public Health at the National School of Public Health. Associate Professor II of the Universidade Federal Fluminense, permanent professor in the Postgraduate Program in Health Collective of the Universidade Federal de Mato Grosso and the PPG Health Collective of UFF. Visiting professor at the University of Padova, Italy (2019) and University of Nottingham, England (2019). We have experience in the area of Collective Health, with emphasis on Worker’s Health, focusing mainly on the following topics: critical theories and health relations, work and environment, contemporary work, surveillance in work-related health, production chains and work-related mental health. . He was coordinator of the PPGSC/ISC/UFMT (2016-2018), member of the Comissão de Avaliação de Programs de Pós-Graduação em Saúde Coletiva da CAPES - Qudriênio (2017-2020) and was associate editor in the Health of Work area of the newspaper Ciência Health Collective (2015-2018), member of the EdUFMT Editorial Council (2020-2022) and associate editor of the Brazilian Journal of Occupational Health. He was a member of the Núcleo Gestor de Ciências Sociais e Humanas em Saúde (2020-2023) of the Brazilian Association of Health Collective (Abrasco).

Biography

GPMAT is a research group at the Federal University of Mato Grosso, led by Professor Carla Leal, a retired labor judge, whose research covers topics such as the work environment, the rights of working women, the LGBTQIA+ community in the labor market, and contemporary slave labor, among others. Formed in 2015/2016, the group has a notable presence in the Mato Grosso scene, with weekly appearances on a radio station in the capital, as well as on two news websites in the state of Mato Grosso, in addition to a podcast available on Spotify. The group’s activities are cross-border, with participation in national and international events, as well as the publication of books and articles in renowned journals. Our researchers are professionals working in related fields and students, whether in the undergraduate or graduate program in law.

title: 2nd International Congress of Ecological Humanities
text:
We will be attending the 2nd International Congress of Ecological Humanities to present some preliminary results regarding the interconnections among workers health and degrating working conditions. This gathering offers a rich space for inter and transdisciplinary dialogue.
Looking forward to connecting with participants who are rethinking human-environment relationships.
The presentation will focus on 20 years of health data and modern slavery records to identify patterns among areas with the highest disease incidence linked to WASH and occupational health. It serves as a foundational step toward identifying causal relationships and improving surveillance mechanisms and risk assessments. By integrating public health data with labour inspections, the study aims to enhance inspection coverage, foster multi-stakeholder collaboration, and strengthen efforts to address labour exploitation and health vulnerabilities simultaneously.
If you’re attending, I’d love to connect!

title: 2º Congresso Internacional de Humanidades Ecológicas
text:
Estaremos presentes no 2º Congresso Internacional de Humanidades Ecológicas para apresentar alguns resultados preliminares sobre as interconexões entre a saúde dos trabalhadores e as condições degradantes de trabalho. Este encontro oferece um espaço rico para o diálogo inter e transdisciplinar.
Estou ansioso para me conectar com participantes que estão repensando as relações entre humanos e meio ambiente.
A apresentação se concentrará em 20 anos de dados de saúde e registros de escravidão moderna para identificar padrões entre áreas com maior incidência de doenças relacionadas a WASH e saúde ocupacional. Ele serve como um passo fundamental para identificar relações causais e melhorar mecanismos de vigilância e avaliações de risco. Ao integrar dados de saúde pública com inspeções trabalhistas, o estudo visa aumentar a cobertura das inspeções, promover a colaboração entre múltiplas partes interessadas e fortalecer os esforços para abordar a exploração trabalhista e as vulnerabilidades de saúde simultaneamente.
Se você for participar, adoraria me conectar com você!

title: about
text:
This research project aims to

Produce a Climate Risk Vulnerability Assessment (CRVA) for agricultural workers in Brazil with respect to climate hazards,
Assess how forced labour practices exacerbate vulnerability and decrease occupational health,
Understand how workers are currently adapting and what their main needs are to increase their resilience to climate change.

We will produce actionable inferences for key stakeholders and policymakers aimed at improving climate risk mitigation strategies in agricultural work and developing adaptation strategies for workers affected by climate change.



How do climate hazards influence the prevalence of occupational health issues, work-related diseases, and slavery-like conditions among agricultural workers in Brazil?
What are the most affected groups and the socioeconomic pathways through which climate change impacts labour rights, wages, and occupational safety within the agricultural sector?
What existing interventions aim to address climate risks and indecent working conditions in agriculture?
How do workers in agriculture respond to climate hazards to promote well-being, food security and sustainable practices?
What insights can be drawn from interdisciplinary research to inform policy and practice for enhancing resilience and well-being?

In answering these questions, we aim to better understand the impact of the climate/work/health nexus on local populations by explicitly linking geographical locations to specific agricultural commodities. This will identify vulnerable areas where targeted interventions can help to mitigate the effects of climate change. The project’s novel, innovative, and integrated methods, data, and analysis will support these more targeted mitigation and adaptation strategies.

title: Climate-Conflict-Vulnerability Index
text: The CCVI metrics are organized hierarchically in three pillars — climate, conflict and vulnerability. Each pillar is based on indicators from publicly available sources, which are further grouped into dimensions. Following the IPCC definition, risk metrics are computed as a function of hazards, exposure and vulnerability.

title: SmartLab
text:
Governments around the world produce large quantities of data relevant to public policies. However, these data are rarely transformed into useful information for decision-making in response to highly complex quests that mark the current situation and demand interventions based on evidence and oriented towards results. On the other hand, the formulation, monitoring and endorsement of programs, projects and public policies are processes that require information. In this context, the SmarlLab initiative emerged to build relevant knowledge for public policies to promote decent work with the use of a low-cost public resource: open public data.
A joint initiative of the MPT and the ILO Brazil originates from the SmartLab Platform, which strengthens cooperation with government, non-governmental and international organizations that promote the agenda and that require information to make decisions about the actions we develop. Through Digital Observatory, the platform also benefits the scientific community, which now has access to information with unprecedented facilities for research. Furthermore, the public flow of information for making decisions based on evidence and oriented towards results benefits general civil society.

title: Mudanças climáticas, trabalho decente e saúde do trabalhador no Brasil: considerações teóricas
text: Esta publicação explora o nexo teórico e conceitual entre mudanças climáticas, saúde dos trabalhadores, trabalho decente, direitos humanos e os Objetivos de Desenvolvimento Sustentável (ODS) da ONU, usando o caso dos trabalhadores agrícolas no Brasil. Estabelece a relação geral entre o risco das mudanças climáticas e as condições de trabalho, os padrões jurídicos e normas internacionais relevantes sobre os direitos dos trabalhadores e as características das condições dos trabalhadores na agricultura brasileira. Oferece uma agenda de investigação convincente com cinco pilares operacionais: (1) investigação, (2) vigilância e monitorização, (3) avaliação de riscos, (4) gestão de riscos e (5) políticas e regulamentos. A estrutura mais holística desenvolvida aqui evita explicações e soluções monocausais, intervenções incompletas e fragmentadas e múltiplas consequências não intencionais de maneiras que podem trazer impacto real aos meios de subsistência e à saúde dos trabalhadores agrícolas brasileiros.

title: The Hidden Cost of Renewables: Modern Slavery in Ethanol supply chain
text:
Enslaved in Ethanol
Ethanol is widely recognized as a important solution to reducing greenhouse gas emissions in transport sector and combating climate change. As the second-largest ethanol producer, Brazil plays a significant role in the global biofuel industry. However, despite its environmental benefits, ethanol production raises serious concerns regarding labour rights, occupational health, and social justice. The recent report Enslaved in Ethanol by Reportér Brasil highlights the exploitation and unsafe working conditions faced by sugarcane workers.

“The situations reported in sugarcane fields linked to their operations include workers killed in fires, forced to sleep on the ground, unable to leave their jobs because of illegal debts imposed by their employers, and even hit by pesticides dropped from airplanes.”

Many workers are subjected to debt bondage and unpredictable wages due to unfair deductions, paying for their own travel, accommodation, and food. Additionally, extreme working hours and lack of formal contracts deny workers access to essential social security benefits. Some workers report sleeping only four hours a night, as long commutes and exhausting shifts make proper rest impossible. Moreover, sugarcane workers are frequently exposed to hazardous pesticides, experience severe physical effort, and high risks of heat-related illnesses.

“Workers reported to inspectors that they had been sprayed on with pesticides. The plane that allegedly did the spraying can be seen in the photo taken by one of them on his cell phone.”




Source: Enslaved in Ethanol. Workers reported to inspectors that they had been sprayed on with pesticides


Addressing these challenges requires stronger enforcement of labour laws, greater corporate accountability, and improved oversight in supply chains. A just transition in the ethanol industry must prioritize not only environmental sustainability but also the protection of workers’ rights and well-being. Governments, companies, and financial institutions must take decisive action to eliminate modern slavery, ensure fair wages, and provide safe working conditions. Ethanol may be a cleaner fuel alternative, but it must not come at the cost of human lives, dignity and fundamental labour rights.

title: LEGO-tellying
text:
As part of the Research Communication program, Mastering the Art of Research Communication: Develop your Skills! by the University of Nottingham’s Research Academy, we had the opportunity to disseminate our projects using non-conventional resources to change mindsets and encourage creativity. It was enjoyable to revisit LEGO — now to continue exploring new ways to share research.
We are working to produce a worker-informed, data-driven climate risk and vulnerability assessment (CRVA) for agricultural workers in Brazil. Each coloured LEGO layer represents a vital piece of the puzzle: climate data, socioeconomic conditions, and workers’ voices. By applying a multi-layer risk assessment, the project will provide insights into the relationship between climate change, workers’ health, and decent work.
A big thank you to Andrew Rowe for introducing such a great initiative.
Sorry for the terrible map, but I ran out of time and green blocks 😅

Part of our goals is to open up new ways of sharing information and learning during all stages of the project, including the process of collecting references, literature review, and discussion among the team.
The following are some proposed tools. We are still in the process of identifying which tools are most effective for our purpose and that fit the project workflow. So, this could evolve in the future.



alphaXiv.org is an online platform designed for open and collaborative discussion on research papers published on arXiv. It allows users to leave comments directly on specific lines within a paper, fostering a more focused and insightful conversation.


As an open access tool, we will include analyses related to our literature review and the process during the development of the methodological framework. We also believe that it will be a powerful tool for collaborating with other stakeholders during the project.




ResearchRabbit is a free online “citation-based literature mapping tool.” It is a visual literature review software mapping tool. The tool connects your research interests to related articles and authors.


We will share our collections of quotes and leave it open to the community to collaborate to identify gaps and strengthen data collection.
See our collection in Research Rabbit: Collection (in process)




Code for Climate Risk Vulnerability Assessment (CRVA) integration will be included to facilitate reproducibility of the project.

title: Todd Landman
text:
Biografia




O Professor Todd Landman é Diretor de Pesquisa do Rights Lab e Professor de Ciência Política na Universidade de Nottingham. Ele trabalha na área de direitos humanos há 25 anos e atualmente pesquisa nas áreas de prevalência da escravidão moderna, antiescravagismo como movimento social e teoria social da escravidão moderna, entre outros tópicos. Atualmente, ele lidera um grande projeto com financiamento externo que avalia riscos aos direitos humanos, incluindo trabalho forçado, no contexto de empresas e cadeias de suprimentos, e trabalha como parte de um grande projeto do governo dos EUA que pesquisa a extensão e as causas da mendicância forçada de crianças no Níger. Seu livro mais recente é “The Rights Track: Sound Evidence on Human Rights and Modern Slavery” (2022).

title: Pedro Igor Galvão
text:
Biografia




Pedro Igor Galvão é bolsista Early Career Fellow do British Council e integrante do programa Measurement and Geographies do Rights Lab (Universidade de Nottingham). Sua pesquisa investiga como o trabalho análogo à escravidão e o desmatamento na Amazônia Legal brasileira se expressam espacialmente por meio de transformações desiguais da paisagem. Ele integra ferramentas de SIG, imagens de satélite e indicadores socioambientais para avaliar correlações entre uso do solo, exploração e injustiça territorial. É graduado em Arquitetura e Urbanismo e está concluindo o mestrado em Ciências do Ambiente pela Universidade Federal do Tocantins (UFT), onde pesquisa a paisagem como produto e instrumento da produção social do espaço. Seu trabalho evidencia como o legado colonial brasileiro se inscreve nos padrões espaciais de segregação, exploração e desigualdade socioambiental. Desde 2018, Pedro atua como pesquisador no Instituto de Atenção às Cidades (IAC/UFT), onde tem coordenado e colaborado em projetos de planejamento e gestão territorial em contextos urbanos e rurais. Sua experiência inclui a elaboração de Planos de Mobilidade Urbana Sustentável (PlanMobs), Planos Diretores Municipais, Relatórios de Licenciamento Ambiental e masterplans em escala regional. Essas iniciativas integram pesquisa acadêmica, consultoria técnica e métodos participativos para apoiar a governança territorial democrática e a justiça espacial.

title: Ana Flávia Trevizan
text:
Biografia




Ana Flávia Trevizan é doutora em Alterações Climáticas e mestre em Direito Agroambiental. Especialista em direito climático e florestal, bem como em questões socioambientais, governança, inclusão e diversidade. Sua pesquisa examina a interseção entre o direito florestal e as políticas públicas ambientais, além de analisar a transparência e as práticas de inclusão e diversidade nas instituições financeiras no contexto da governança climática no Brasil. Atualmente, contribui para o desenvolvimento de soluções jurídicas e sustentáveis para desafios socioambientais no Rights Lab (Universidade de Nottingham). É autora de diversas publicações internacionais e membro de importantes grupos de pesquisa, como o CENSE (UNL), o CEDAT (URV) e o GPMAT (UFMT).

Nossos pesquisadores são profissionais atuantes em áreas afins e estudantes, seja na graduação ou na pós-graduação em direito.

Biografia
Edgar Rodríguez-Huerta trabalha como parte do Measurement and Geography Programme para pesquisar as interações entre sistemas socioecológicos, mudanças climáticas e escravidão moderna. Ele conduz pesquisas quantitativas por meio de múltiplas abordagens de pensamento sistêmico, como Avaliação do Ciclo de Vida Social e análise de dados secundários, modelagem climática, metabolismo social e redes complexas para explorar as dimensões humanas de diferentes cadeias de suprimentos (por exemplo, suprimento de alimentos, painéis solares e fornos de tijolos). Ele concluiu um PhD em Ciência da Sustentabilidade e, com sua formação em ciência de dados e Business Intelligence, é um entusiasta da visualização de dados para comunicar e publicar os resultados técnicos entre as partes interessadas e facilitar a tomada de decisões.

title: O custo oculto das energias renováveis: Pessoas Em Condição Análoga À De Escravo na cadeia de fornecimento de Etanol
text:
Como parte do programa de Comunicação de Pesquisa, Dominando a Arte da Comunicação de Pesquisa: Desenvolva suas Habilidades! da Academia de Pesquisa da Universidade de Nottingham, tivemos a oportunidade de disseminar nossos projetos usando recursos não convencionais para mudar mentalidades e incentivar a criatividade. Foi agradável revisitar o LEGO — agora para continuar explorando novas maneiras de compartilhar pesquisas.
Estamos trabalhando para produzir uma avaliação de risco climático e vulnerabilidade (CRVA) baseada em dados e informada pelos trabalhadores para trabalhadores agrícolas no Brasil. Cada camada colorida de LEGO representa uma peça vital do quebra-cabeça: dados climáticos, condições socioeconômicas e vozes dos trabalhadores. Ao aplicar uma avaliação de risco multicamadas, o projeto fornecerá insights sobre a relação entre mudanças climáticas, saúde dos trabalhadores e trabalho decente.
Um grande agradecimento a Andrew Rowe por apresentar uma iniciativa tão boa.

title: O custo oculto das energias renováveis: Pessoas Em Condição Análoga À De Escravo na cadeia de fornecimento de Etanol
text:
Escravizado do Etanol
O etanol é amplamente reconhecido como uma solução importante para reduzir as emissões de gases de efeito estufa no setor de transporte e combater as mudanças climáticas. Como segundo maior produtor de etanol, o Brasil desempenha um papel significativo na indústria global de biocombustíveis. Entretanto, apesar de seus benefícios ambientais, a produção de etanol levanta sérias preocupações em relação aos direitos trabalhistas, saúde ocupacional e justiça social. O relatório recente Escravizado do Etanol by Reportér Brasil highlights the exploitation and unsafe working conditions faced by sugarcane workers.

“Trabalhadores mortos em queimadas, obrigados a dormir no chão, forçados a trabalhar por conta de dívidas ilegais impostas pelo empregador e até mesmo atingidos por agrotóxicos lançados de aviões estão entre as situações reportadas em canaviais ligados às suas operações.”

Muitos trabalhadores são submetidos à servidão por dívidas e salários imprevisíveis devido a deduções injustas, pagando suas próprias viagens, acomodações e alimentação. Além disso, horários de trabalho extremos e a falta de contratos formais negam aos trabalhadores o acesso a benefícios essenciais da previdência social. Alguns trabalhadores relatam dormir apenas quatro horas por noite, pois longos deslocamentos e turnos exaustivos impossibilitam um descanso adequado. Além disso, os trabalhadores da cana-de-açúcar são frequentemente expostos a pesticidas perigosos, sofrem esforços físicos intensos e correm altos riscos de doenças relacionadas ao calor.

“Durante resgate ocorrido em fazendas de cinco municípios de Goiás e Minas Gerais, trabalhadores relataram aos fiscais que foram atingidos por agrotóxicos. Na foto, tirada pelo celular de um deles, é possível ver o avião que supostamente realizou a pulverização”




Fonte: Escravizado do Etanol. Trabalhadores relataram aos inspetores que foram pulverizados com pesticidas


Enfrentar esses desafios exige uma aplicação mais rigorosa das leis trabalhistas, maior responsabilização corporativa e melhor supervisão nas cadeias de suprimentos. Uma transição justa na indústria do etanol deve priorizar não apenas a sustentabilidade ambiental, mas também a proteção dos direitos e do bem-estar dos trabalhadores. Governos, empresas e instituições financeiras devem tomar medidas decisivas para eliminar a escravidão moderna, garantir salários justos e fornecer condições de trabalho seguras. O etanol pode ser uma alternativa de combustível mais limpa, mas não deve ser feito à custa de vidas humanas, dignidade e direitos trabalhistas fundamentais.

title: Climate Change, Decent Work and Workers’ Health in Brazil: Theoretical Considerations
text: This paper explores the theoretical and conceptual nexus between climate change, workers’ health, decent work, human rights, and the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) using the case of agricultural workers in Brazil. It establishes the overall relationship between climate change risk and working conditions, relevant international legal standards and norms on worker rights, and the features of worker conditions in Brazilian agriculture. It offers a compelling research agenda with five operational pillars: (1) research, (2) surveillance and monitoring, (3) risk assessment, (4) risk management, and (5) policies and regulations. The more holistic framework developed here avoids monocausal explanations and solutions, incomplete and fragmented interventions, and multiple unintended consequences in ways that can bring real impact to the livelihoods and health of Brazilian agricultural workers.

Publishing
When you’re ready to let the world (or just a few people) see your work, check out the Quarto publishing section of the Guide. title: SmartLab
text:
SmartLab

SmartLab

Governos de todo o mundo produzem grandes quantidades de dados relevantes para políticas públicas. Entretanto, raramente esses dados se transformam em informações úteis à tomada de decisões a respeito de questões de alta complexidade que marcam a atualidade e que exigem intervenções baseadas em evidências e orientadas para resultados. Por outro lado, a formulação, o monitoramento e a avaliação de programas, projetos e políticas públicas são processos que exigem informações. Nesse contexto, a iniciativa SmarlLab surgiu para construir conhecimento relevante para políticas públicas de promoção do trabalho decente com o uso de um recurso público de baixíssimo custo: dados públicos abertos. A iniciativa conjunta do MPT e da OIT Brasil deu origem à Plataforma SmartLab, que tem fortalecido a cooperação com organizações governamentais, não-governamentais e internacionais que atuam na promoção dessa agenda e que precisam de informações para tomar decisões sobre as ações que desenvolvem. Por meio de Observatórios Digitais, a plataforma beneficia também a comunidade científica, que passa a ter acesso a informações com facilidade sem precedentes para pesquisa. Além disso, o fluxo público de informações para tomada de decisões baseadas em evidências e orientadas para resultados beneficia a sociedade civil em geral.

title: Climate and Occupational Health and Decent Work Nexus: Worker’s Vulnerabilities
text:
Project idea
This research will advance our understanding of the relationship between climate change, occupational health, and decent work, in the case of Brazilian agriculture, in partnership with Universidade Federal Fluminense. The project will produce a worker-informed, data-driven climate risk and vulnerability assessment (CRVA) for agricultural workers in Brazil concerning climate hazards. It will assess how indecent work practices exacerbate vulnerability and decrease occupational health. The project provides valuable insights towards developing targeted mitigation and adaptation strategies by applying a multi-layer risk assessment approach that integrates climate models, socio-economic data, and qualitative data from participatory methods such as worker voice data. This project supports the broader aspirations for achieving decent work conditions, as set out in UN Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 8, and linked with SDG 3, improving agricultural workers’ overall health and well-being.
Funder: British Academy’s ODA Challenge-Oriented Research Grants 2024 Programme Duration: 18 months (June 24 to Dec 25)
Rights Lab project lead: Edgar Rodríguez-Huerta Programme: Measurement and Geographies

Biography




Ana Flávia Trevizan holds a PhD in Climate Change and a Master’s in Agri-environmental Law. She specialises in climate and forestry law, as well as socio-environmental issues, governance, inclusion, and diversity. Her research examines the intersection of forestry law and environmental public policies, while also analysing transparency and inclusion and diversity practices within financial institutions in the context of climate governance in Brazil. Currently, she contributes to the development of legal and sustainable solutions for socio-environmental challenges at the Rights Lab (University of Nottingham). She is the author of several international publications and a member of prominent research groups, including CENSE (UNL), CEDAT (URV), and GPMAT (UFMT).

title: Pedro Igor Galvão
text:
Biography




Pedro Igor Galvão is a British Council Early Career Fellow and a member of the Measurement and Geographies Programme at the Rights Lab (University of Nottingham). His research explores how forced labour and deforestation in the Brazilian Legal Amazon are spatially expressed through unequal landscape transformations. He integrates GIS, satellite imagery, and socio-environmental indicators to assess correlations between land use, exploitation, and territorial injustice. He holds a degree in Architecture and Urbanism and is completing a Master’s in Environmental Sciences at the Federal University of Tocantins (UFT), where he investigates landscape as both product and instrument of the social production of space. His work reveals how Brazil’s colonial legacy is inscribed in spatial patterns of segregation, exploitation, and socio-environmental inequality. Since 2018, Pedro has worked as a researcher at the Instituto de Atenção às Cidades (IAC/UFT), where he has coordinated and contributed to planning and territorial management projects across urban and rural contexts. His experience includes the development of Sustainable Urban Mobility Plans (PlanMobs), Municipal Master Plans, Environmental Licensing Reports, and regional-scale masterplans. These initiatives integrate academic research, technical consultancy, and participatory methods to support democratic territorial governance and spatial justice.

Biography




Professor Todd Landman is the Rights Lab Research Director and Professor of Political Science at the University of Nottingham. He has worked in the field of human rights for 25 years, and is currently researching in the areas of modern slavery prevalence, anti-slavery as a social movement, and the social theory of modern slavery, among other topics. He currently leads a large externally-funded project assessing human rights risks, including forced labour, in the context of business and supply chains, and works as part of a large US-government project that is researching the extent and causes of forced child begging in Niger. His most recent book is The Rights Track: Sound Evidence on Human Rights and Modern Slavery (2022).
